ResponseText: Almost always, the point being made is that two people in a homosexual relationship will never be able to conceive children because it's a sort of relationship outside of the procreative norm. That's just the reality of the situation. That there are are non-natural ways to get around that reality is beside the point. (Heck, I've even heard gays bring up--as wishful thinking, no doubt--the bizarro tabloid-like news accounts of womb transplants into men, and so forth.) I suppose one could still 'walk' around if he or she forwent normal walking for walking on their hands everywhere they went. The walking 'organs' (one's legs) would still not be "automatically broken". The usual 'rape-has-nothing-to-do-with-attraction' thing is a tragic over-simplification. If it were true, all rapists would target men and women with equal abuse, and everyone knows that's just not the case.

To Jyoshu: I am legally allowed to marry a man, and I cannot procreate. I am post-menopausal, and no one tries to prevent me from marrying a man, even though a marriage between me and a man would be "outside the procreative norm," to quote you. I think the argument that gay people cannot procreate as same-sex couples is just cover to try to mask homophobia. What really drives the anti-same-sex marriage arguments is homophobia. Fortunately, people can un-learn homophobia. Homophobia is learned, but clinging to homophobia is a choice. People can choose to stop being homophobic.

QuoteText: To Jyoshu: I am legally allowed to marry a man, and I cannot procreate. I am post-menopausal, and no one tries to prevent me from marrying a man, even though a marriage between me and a man would be "outside the procreative norm," to quote you.
ResponseText: IMO, this issue of recognizing gay unions and that of the biological normalcy of the relationship are not necessarily the same issue. I never said the legality of gay marriage rests on those merits. But in the example you gave, you are still a woman mating with a man. The inability to procreate in that case is due to age, not due to biological incompatibility.

Jyoshu, my inability to reproduce with a man is due to my biological inability to do so. That's no different, in essence, from what you call "biological incompatibility." Playing with words does not make my biological inability to reproduce with a man any different from my biological inability to reproduce with a woman. I am biologically unable to reproduce with either a man or a woman. That should not be a reason to bar me from marrying either one. If you are not arguing that this biological inability to reproduce is a reason to bar people from marrying each other, then why did you bring it up?

QuoteText: IMO, this issue of recognizing gay unions and that of the biological normalcy of the relationship are not necessarily the same issue. I never said the legality of gay marriage rests on those merits. But in the example you gave, you are still a woman mating with a man. The inability to procreate in that case is due to age, not due to biological incompatibility.
ResponseText: many things can cause infertility in males and females at any age, but whats most relevant here is genetic infertility. males can have something called 'Y chromosome micro deletion', which in short means that he has some missing some base pairs in his Y chromosome - the chromosome responsible for sperm production. and if the information for sperm production is missing, that man is subsequently infertile from birth. he is still legally able to marry a woman, although he cannot biologically procreate. both males and females can have pituitary gland disorders which can cause an absense of hormones such as LH (lutenizing hormone), FSH (follicle stimulating hormone), testosterone or estrogen which are all responsible for fertility. - regarded hormonal disorders can sometimes be treated, but the fact still remains, those who dont treat their hormonal disorders which cause infertility can still get married to the opposite sex. EDIT: a couple may also be biologically incompatible. a friend of mine and his girlfriend are going through some rough times right now because their blood is not compatible with one another, and although they can procreate, the baby will have major blood problems. theyre currently figuring it out and getting medical treatment, but STILL - they are still legally able to get married despite their biological incompatibility.
